description: Explore quantum mechanics, nuclear physics, special relativity, and semiconductor physics that revolutionized our understanding of the universe

slides.title: Welcome to Modern Physics
slides.content:
# Introduction to Modern Physics

Welcome to **Modern Physics** - the revolutionary science of the 20th century that transformed our understanding of reality!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Quantum Mechanics** - Physics at atomic scales
- **Photoelectric Effect** - Light as particles
- **Atomic Models** - How atoms are structured
- **Nuclear Physics** - The heart of atoms
- **Special Relativity** - Space, time, and speed
- **Semiconductors** - The foundation of electronics

> **Fun Fact:** Modern physics began when a few "small problems" in classical physics led to completely revolutionary ideas!

## Why Modern Physics Matters:
- Powers all electronic devices (quantum mechanics)
- Explains nuclear energy and weapons
- GPS satellites use relativistic corrections
- Medical imaging (PET, MRI) relies on these principles
- Enables lasers, LEDs, and solar cells

## The Two Pillars:

| Pillar | Domain | Key Figures |
|--------|--------|-------------|
| Quantum Mechanics | Very small (atoms) | Planck, Bohr, Heisenberg |
| Relativity | Very fast (near light speed) | Einstein |

Let's explore the strange and wonderful world of modern physics!

slides.title: The Photoelectric Effect
slides.content:
# The Photoelectric Effect

The **photoelectric effect** is the emission of electrons from a metal when light shines on it.

## Classical Prediction (Wrong):
- Any light should eventually emit electrons
- Brighter light = more energetic electrons
- Just need enough time for energy to build up

## Experimental Results:
- Only light above certain frequency works
- Electrons emitted instantly, no delay
- Brighter light = more electrons, not more energy
- Higher frequency = more energetic electrons

## Einstein's Explanation (1905):

Light consists of particles called **photons**.

### Photon Energy:
```
E = h x f = hc / lambda
```

Where:
- **h** = Planck's constant = 6.63 x 10^-34 J s
- **f** = Frequency
- **lambda** = Wavelength

### Photoelectric Equation:
```
KE_max = h x f - W
```

Where:
- **KE_max** = Maximum kinetic energy of electron
- **W** = Work function (minimum energy to free electron)

## Threshold Frequency:

```
f_threshold = W / h
```

Below this frequency, NO electrons are emitted regardless of intensity.

## Applications:
- Solar cells
- Light meters
- Automatic doors
- Night vision devices

> **Nobel Prize:** Einstein won the 1921 Nobel Prize for explaining the photoelectric effect, not for relativity!

slides.title: Wave-Particle Duality
slides.content:
# Wave-Particle Duality

**Wave-particle duality** states that all matter and energy exhibits both wave and particle properties.

## Light as Both:

### Particle Evidence:
- Photoelectric effect
- Compton scattering
- Photons carry momentum

### Wave Evidence:
- Interference patterns
- Diffraction
- Polarization

## Matter Waves (de Broglie):

**All matter has wave properties!**

```
lambda = h / p = h / (m x v)
```

Where:
- **lambda** = de Broglie wavelength
- **p** = Momentum
- **m** = Mass
- **v** = Velocity

## Example:

| Object | Mass (kg) | Velocity (m/s) | Wavelength |
|--------|-----------|----------------|------------|
| Electron | 9.1 x 10^-31 | 10^6 | 0.7 nm (detectable) |
| Baseball | 0.15 | 40 | 10^-34 m (undetectable) |

## Electron Diffraction:

- Electrons passed through crystal
- Diffraction pattern observed
- Proves electrons have wave nature
- Used in electron microscopes

## The Uncertainty Principle:

```
Delta x x Delta p >= h / (4 x pi)
```

- Cannot simultaneously know exact position AND momentum
- Not due to measurement limitations
- Fundamental property of nature

> **Key Insight:** The wave-particle duality is not about light "switching" between forms - it's BOTH at once, behaving differently depending on the experiment!

slides.title: The Bohr Model of the Atom
slides.content:
# The Bohr Model of the Atom

Niels Bohr proposed a revolutionary model of the atom in 1913.

## Bohr's Postulates:

### 1. Quantized Orbits:
- Electrons orbit nucleus in specific allowed orbits
- Only certain radii are permitted
- Orbits have specific energy levels

### 2. Stable Orbits:
- Electrons in allowed orbits do NOT radiate energy
- They are "stationary states"

### 3. Quantum Jumps:
- Electrons can jump between levels
- Absorb photon: jump to higher level
- Emit photon: drop to lower level
- Photon energy = energy difference

## Energy Levels in Hydrogen:

```
E_n = -13.6 eV / n^2
```

Where n = 1, 2, 3... (principal quantum number)

| Level | n | Energy (eV) |
|-------|---|-------------|
| Ground state | 1 | -13.6 |
| 1st excited | 2 | -3.4 |
| 2nd excited | 3 | -1.51 |
| Ionized | infinity | 0 |

## Spectral Lines:

### Emission Spectrum:
Photon emitted when electron drops:
```
E_photon = E_high - E_low = h x f
```

### Absorption Spectrum:
Photon absorbed when electron jumps up.

## Limitations of Bohr Model:
- Works only for hydrogen-like atoms
- Cannot explain fine structure
- No explanation of WHY orbits are quantized
- Replaced by quantum mechanics

> **Historical Impact:** Despite limitations, Bohr's model correctly predicted hydrogen's spectrum and opened the door to quantum theory!

slides.title: Quantum Mechanics Basics
slides.content:
# Quantum Mechanics Basics

**Quantum mechanics** is the complete theory of atomic and subatomic behavior.

## Key Concepts:

### Wave Function:
- Describes quantum state of particle
- Symbol: psi (written as "psi")
- |psi|^2 gives probability density
- Solution to Schrodinger equation

### Probability Interpretation:
- Cannot predict exact outcomes
- Can only predict probabilities
- Many measurements give statistical distribution

### Superposition:
- Particle in multiple states simultaneously
- Measurement collapses to one state
- Example: Schrodinger's cat thought experiment

## Quantum Numbers:

Electrons in atoms described by four quantum numbers:

| Number | Symbol | Values | Describes |
|--------|--------|--------|----------|
| Principal | n | 1, 2, 3... | Energy level/size |
| Angular momentum | l | 0 to n-1 | Orbital shape |
| Magnetic | m_l | -l to +l | Orbital orientation |
| Spin | m_s | +1/2 or -1/2 | Electron spin |

## Pauli Exclusion Principle:

> **No two electrons in an atom can have the same four quantum numbers.**

This explains:
- Electron shell filling
- Chemical properties
- The periodic table

## Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle:

```
Delta x x Delta p >= h / (4 x pi)
Delta E x Delta t >= h / (4 x pi)
```

> **Key Insight:** Quantum mechanics is not just "small classical physics" - it requires abandoning many classical concepts like definite paths!

slides.title: Nuclear Structure
slides.content:
# Nuclear Structure

The atomic **nucleus** contains protons and neutrons bound by the strong force.

## Nuclear Components:

### Protons:
- Positive charge (+e)
- Mass: 1.673 x 10^-27 kg
- Determines element (atomic number Z)

### Neutrons:
- No charge
- Mass: 1.675 x 10^-27 kg
- Affects stability (isotopes)

### Nucleons:
- Collective term for protons and neutrons
- Mass number A = Z + N

## Nuclear Notation:

```
^A_Z X
```

Example: Carbon-14 = ^14_6 C (6 protons, 8 neutrons)

## Isotopes:

- Same element (same Z)
- Different number of neutrons
- Same chemical properties, different nuclear properties

| Isotope | Protons | Neutrons | Stable? |
|---------|---------|----------|--------|
| H-1 | 1 | 0 | Yes |
| H-2 (D) | 1 | 1 | Yes |
| H-3 (T) | 1 | 2 | No |
| C-12 | 6 | 6 | Yes |
| C-14 | 6 | 8 | No |

## Nuclear Forces:

### Strong Nuclear Force:
- Holds nucleons together
- Very short range (~1 fm)
- Overcomes proton repulsion
- Strongest of all forces

### Why Large Nuclei Are Unstable:
- Strong force is short-range
- Electromagnetic repulsion is long-range
- Large nuclei: protons too far for strong force
- Results in radioactive decay

> **Nuclear Size:** Nuclei are about 10^-15 m across - 100,000 times smaller than atoms!

slides.title: Radioactivity
slides.content:
# Radioactivity

**Radioactivity** is the spontaneous emission of particles or energy from unstable nuclei.

## Types of Radiation:

### Alpha (a) Decay:
- Emits helium nucleus (2p + 2n)
- Low penetrating power (stopped by paper)
- High ionizing power
- Z decreases by 2, A decreases by 4

### Beta (b) Decay:
- Beta-minus: neutron -> proton + electron
- Beta-plus: proton -> neutron + positron
- Medium penetrating power (stopped by aluminum)
- Z changes by 1, A unchanged

### Gamma (g) Decay:
- High-energy photon
- High penetrating power (needs lead/concrete)
- No change in Z or A
- Often accompanies alpha or beta decay

## Comparison:

| Property | Alpha | Beta | Gamma |
|----------|-------|------|-------|
| Particle | He nucleus | Electron | Photon |
| Charge | +2 | -1 or +1 | 0 |
| Penetration | Low | Medium | High |
| Ionization | High | Medium | Low |
| Stopped by | Paper | Aluminum | Lead |

## Half-Life:

**Half-life (t_1/2)** is time for half the nuclei to decay.

```
N = N_0 x (1/2)^(t/t_1/2)
```

| Isotope | Half-life |
|---------|----------|
| U-238 | 4.5 billion years |
| C-14 | 5,730 years |
| Co-60 | 5.27 years |
| I-131 | 8 days |
| Po-218 | 3 minutes |

## Applications:
- Carbon dating (archaeology)
- Medical tracers and treatment
- Smoke detectors (Am-241)
- Power sources (RTGs)

> **Randomness:** We cannot predict WHEN a particular nucleus will decay, only the probability. Half-life is a statistical property!

slides.title: Nuclear Fission
slides.content:
# Nuclear Fission

**Fission** is the splitting of a heavy nucleus into lighter nuclei, releasing energy.

## How Fission Works:

1. Heavy nucleus (e.g., U-235) absorbs neutron
2. Nucleus becomes unstable
3. Splits into two medium-mass fragments
4. Releases 2-3 neutrons + energy

## Fission Equation Example:

```
U-235 + neutron -> Ba-141 + Kr-92 + 3 neutrons + energy
```

## Energy Release:

### Mass Defect:
- Products have slightly less mass than reactants
- Missing mass converted to energy

### Einstein's Equation:
```
E = m x c^2
```

Where c = 3 x 10^8 m/s

### Energy per Fission:
- About 200 MeV per U-235 fission
- Compare: chemical reactions release ~1 eV
- Fission is ~200 million times more energetic!

## Chain Reaction:

- Each fission releases 2-3 neutrons
- These can trigger more fissions
- **Critical mass:** minimum mass for sustained chain reaction

### Types:
| Type | Neutron Population | Use |
|------|-------------------|-----|
| Subcritical | Decreasing | Cannot sustain |
| Critical | Constant | Power plants |
| Supercritical | Increasing | Bombs |

## Nuclear Reactor:

- Controlled critical chain reaction
- **Moderator:** Slows neutrons (water, graphite)
- **Control rods:** Absorb neutrons (cadmium, boron)
- Heat produces steam for electricity

> **Power Density:** 1 kg of U-235 releases energy equivalent to about 3,000 tons of coal!

slides.title: Nuclear Fusion
slides.content:
# Nuclear Fusion

**Fusion** is the combining of light nuclei to form heavier nuclei, releasing energy.

## How Fusion Works:

1. Light nuclei (hydrogen isotopes) approach
2. Must overcome electromagnetic repulsion
3. Strong force takes over at close range
4. Nuclei fuse, releasing energy

## Fusion in the Sun:

### Proton-Proton Chain:
```
4 H-1 -> He-4 + 2 positrons + 2 neutrinos + energy
```

### Energy Release:
- 0.7% of mass converted to energy
- Sun converts 600 million tons of H per second
- Produces 3.8 x 10^26 Watts

## Earth-based Fusion:

### D-T Reaction (most accessible):
```
H-2 + H-3 -> He-4 + neutron + 17.6 MeV
```

### Requirements:
- Temperature: 100+ million degrees
- Plasma must be confined
- Long enough confinement time

### Approaches:
| Method | Description |
|--------|------------|
| Magnetic confinement | Tokamak, stellarator |
| Inertial confinement | Laser compression |
| ITER | International fusion project |

## Fusion vs Fission:

| Aspect | Fission | Fusion |
|--------|---------|--------|
| Fuel | Uranium, plutonium | Hydrogen isotopes |
| Products | Radioactive waste | Helium (harmless) |
| Safety | Meltdown risk | Inherently safe |
| Status | Working reactors | Still developing |

## Advantages of Fusion:
- Nearly limitless fuel (deuterium from water)
- No carbon emissions
- Less radioactive waste
- No meltdown risk

> **The Holy Grail:** Fusion has been "30 years away" for decades, but recent advances are bringing it closer to reality!

slides.title: Special Relativity - Basics
slides.content:
# Special Relativity - Basics

Einstein's **Special Relativity** (1905) revolutionized our understanding of space and time.

## The Two Postulates:

### 1. Principle of Relativity:
> **The laws of physics are the same in all inertial reference frames.**

### 2. Constant Speed of Light:
> **The speed of light in vacuum is the same for all observers, regardless of their motion.**

```
c = 3 x 10^8 m/s (exact: 299,792,458 m/s)
```

## Consequences:

### Relativity of Simultaneity:
- Events simultaneous in one frame may not be in another
- There is no universal "now"

### Time Dilation:
- Moving clocks run slower
- Faster motion = slower time

### Length Contraction:
- Moving objects appear shorter (in direction of motion)
- Faster motion = more contraction

## Why It Seems Strange:

- Effects only noticeable at high speeds
- Our intuition comes from slow-speed experience
- At everyday speeds, classical physics is excellent approximation

## When Relativity Matters:

| Speed | Notable Effects |
|-------|----------------|
| 10% c | Measurable effects |
| 50% c | Factor of 1.15 in time dilation |
| 90% c | Factor of 2.3 in time dilation |
| 99% c | Factor of 7 in time dilation |
| 99.9% c | Factor of 22 in time dilation |

> **GPS Satellites:** Must correct for both special and general relativity, or positioning would drift by ~10 km per day!

slides.title: Time Dilation and Length Contraction
slides.content:
# Time Dilation and Length Contraction

## Time Dilation:

> **Moving clocks tick more slowly.**

### Formula:
```
t = t_0 / sqrt(1 - v^2/c^2)
```

Or using gamma factor:
```
gamma = 1 / sqrt(1 - v^2/c^2)
t = gamma x t_0
```

Where:
- **t** = Time measured by stationary observer
- **t_0** = Proper time (clock's own frame)
- **v** = Relative velocity
- **c** = Speed of light

### Example:
Spacecraft moving at 0.8c
```
gamma = 1 / sqrt(1 - 0.64) = 1 / sqrt(0.36) = 1/0.6 = 1.67
```
1 hour on ship = 1.67 hours on Earth

## Length Contraction:

> **Moving objects are shorter in direction of motion.**

### Formula:
```
L = L_0 x sqrt(1 - v^2/c^2) = L_0 / gamma
```

Where:
- **L** = Length measured by stationary observer
- **L_0** = Proper length (object's own frame)

### Example:
Same spacecraft (0.8c), proper length 100 m:
```
L = 100 / 1.67 = 60 m
```

## Twin Paradox:

- Twin A stays on Earth
- Twin B travels to star and back at high speed
- Twin B ages less than Twin A
- Resolution: B's frame is not inertial (accelerates)

## Experimental Evidence:

- Muon lifetime extension (cosmic rays)
- Particle accelerators
- Atomic clocks on jets
- GPS satellites

> **Muons:** Created in upper atmosphere, should decay before reaching ground. Time dilation allows them to survive the journey!

slides.title: Mass-Energy Equivalence
slides.content:
# Mass-Energy Equivalence

Einstein's famous equation connects mass and energy.

## The Equation:

```
E = m x c^2
```

Where:
- **E** = Energy (Joules)
- **m** = Mass (kilograms)
- **c** = Speed of light = 3 x 10^8 m/s

## What It Means:

- Mass IS a form of energy
- Energy has mass
- They can be converted into each other

## Energy Content of Mass:

| Mass | Energy Equivalent |
|------|------------------|
| 1 kg | 9 x 10^16 J |
| 1 g | 9 x 10^13 J |
| 1 kg | ~2.5 billion kWh |
| 1 kg | Hiroshima bomb |

## Relativistic Energy:

### Total Energy:
```
E_total = gamma x m x c^2
```

### Rest Energy:
```
E_rest = m x c^2
```

### Kinetic Energy:
```
KE = E_total - E_rest = (gamma - 1) x m x c^2
```

## Relativistic Momentum:

```
p = gamma x m x v
```

## Energy-Momentum Relation:

```
E^2 = (pc)^2 + (mc^2)^2
```

For photons (m = 0): E = pc

## Applications:

| Process | Mass-Energy Conversion |
|---------|------------------------|
| Nuclear fission | ~0.1% of mass |
| Nuclear fusion | ~0.7% of mass |
| Matter-antimatter | 100% of mass |
| Chemical reactions | ~10^-9 |

> **Enormous Energy:** The mass lost when you burn 1 kg of coal (about 1/10 billionth of a gram) produces more energy than the mass of 7 cars!

slides.title: Semiconductors
slides.content:
# Semiconductors

**Semiconductors** have electrical conductivity between conductors and insulators.

## Band Theory:

### Energy Bands:
- **Valence band:** Filled with electrons, bonding
- **Conduction band:** Empty (or partially filled), allows current
- **Band gap:** Energy required to move electron to conduction band

### Material Classification:

| Material | Band Gap | Conductivity |
|----------|----------|-------------|
| Conductor | Zero/overlapping | High |
| Semiconductor | Small (0.1-3 eV) | Medium, controllable |
| Insulator | Large (>3 eV) | Very low |

## Intrinsic Semiconductors:

- Pure silicon or germanium
- At room temperature, some electrons jump to conduction band
- Leaves "holes" in valence band
- Both electrons and holes conduct current

## Extrinsic (Doped) Semiconductors:

### N-type:
- Add atoms with 5 valence electrons (phosphorus, arsenic)
- Extra electrons available for conduction
- Electrons are majority carriers

### P-type:
- Add atoms with 3 valence electrons (boron, gallium)
- Creates "holes" that act as positive charges
- Holes are majority carriers

## Temperature Effect:

- Higher temperature = more electrons in conduction band
- Semiconductor conductivity INCREASES with temperature
- Opposite of metals!

> **Silicon Revolution:** Silicon's semiconductor properties enabled the computer age. Silicon Valley is named after it!

slides.title: Semiconductor Devices
slides.content:
# Semiconductor Devices

## The P-N Junction Diode:

Joining p-type and n-type semiconductors creates a diode.

### Depletion Region:
- Electrons and holes recombine at junction
- Creates region with no mobile charges
- Built-in electric field forms

### Forward Bias:
- Positive to p-side, negative to n-side
- Reduces depletion region
- Current flows (diode ON)

### Reverse Bias:
- Negative to p-side, positive to n-side
- Widens depletion region
- Very little current (diode OFF)

## Applications of Diodes:

| Type | Application |
|------|------------|
| Rectifier | AC to DC conversion |
| LED | Light emission |
| Photodiode | Light detection |
| Zener | Voltage regulation |
| Solar cell | Energy generation |

## Light Emitting Diode (LED):

- Forward-biased diode
- Electrons recombine with holes
- Release energy as photons
- Color depends on band gap

## Transistors:

### Bipolar Junction Transistor (BJT):
- Three layers: NPN or PNP
- Small base current controls large collector current
- Current amplifier

### Field Effect Transistor (FET):
- Voltage controls current
- Used in most modern circuits
- High input impedance

## Applications:

| Device | Uses |
|--------|------|
| Transistor | Amplifiers, switches, processors |
| LED | Displays, lighting, communication |
| Solar cell | Power generation |
| Photodiode | Cameras, sensors |

> **Moore's Law:** Transistor density on chips doubles about every 2 years. Modern chips have billions of transistors!

slides.title: Lasers
slides.content:
# Lasers

**LASER** = Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation

## How Lasers Work:

### 1. Population Inversion:
- Normally, more atoms in ground state
- Energy pumping puts more atoms in excited state
- "Inverted" population needed for laser action

### 2. Stimulated Emission:
- Photon passes excited atom
- Triggers release of identical photon
- Same frequency, phase, and direction
- Chain reaction in laser medium

### 3. Optical Cavity:
- Mirrors at both ends
- Light bounces back and forth
- Builds intensity
- Partially transparent mirror lets beam out

## Properties of Laser Light:

| Property | Meaning |
|----------|--------|
| Monochromatic | Single wavelength (color) |
| Coherent | All waves in phase |
| Collimated | Parallel beam, low divergence |
| High intensity | Energy concentrated |

## Types of Lasers:

| Type | Medium | Applications |
|------|--------|-------------|
| Helium-Neon | Gas | Pointers, alignment |
| CO2 | Gas | Cutting, welding |
| Ruby | Solid | First laser (1960) |
| Semiconductor | Solid | Barcode readers, CDs |
| Fiber | Optical fiber | Communications |

## Applications:

- Communications (fiber optics)
- Manufacturing (cutting, welding)
- Medicine (surgery, eye treatment)
- Entertainment (shows, pointers)
- Scientific research
- Barcode scanners, CD/DVD/Blu-ray

> **Fun Fact:** The first laser was demonstrated in 1960. Now even your phone likely contains several semiconductor lasers!

slides.title: Quantum Applications
slides.content:
# Quantum Applications

## Quantum Tunneling:

- Particles can pass through barriers classically impossible
- Wave function extends into barrier region
- Probability of appearing on other side

### Applications:
| Technology | Use of Tunneling |
|------------|------------------|
| Tunnel diode | Fast switches |
| STM (microscope) | Atomic-scale imaging |
| Flash memory | Data storage |
| Nuclear fusion | Stars work! |

## Superconductivity:

- Zero electrical resistance
- Occurs below critical temperature
- Expels magnetic fields (Meissner effect)

### Applications:
- MRI machines
- Particle accelerators
- Quantum computers
- Maglev trains

## Quantum Computing:

### Qubits:
- Unlike classical bits (0 or 1)
- Qubits can be BOTH simultaneously (superposition)
- Enables parallel processing

### Quantum Entanglement:
- Particles correlated regardless of distance
- Measuring one instantly affects the other
- "Spooky action at a distance" (Einstein)

### Applications:
- Cryptography
- Drug discovery
- Optimization problems
- AI and machine learning

## Scanning Tunneling Microscope (STM):

- Uses quantum tunneling
- Maps atomic surfaces
- Can image individual atoms!
- Nobel Prize 1986

> **The Future:** Quantum technologies are progressing rapidly. Quantum computers may soon solve problems impossible for classical computers!

slides.title: Summary and Key Concepts
slides.content:
# Modern Physics Summary

## Quantum Mechanics:
- Light and matter have wave-particle duality
- E = h x f for photons
- de Broglie: lambda = h/p for matter
- Uncertainty principle limits simultaneous knowledge
- Atoms have quantized energy levels

## Nuclear Physics:

| Process | What Happens | Energy |
|---------|--------------|--------|
| Radioactivity | Unstable nuclei decay | Released |
| Fission | Heavy nucleus splits | ~200 MeV |
| Fusion | Light nuclei combine | ~17 MeV (D-T) |

## Special Relativity:
- Speed of light is constant for all observers
- Time dilation: t = gamma x t_0
- Length contraction: L = L_0/gamma
- Mass-energy: E = mc^2

## Semiconductors:
- Band gap determines conductivity
- N-type: excess electrons
- P-type: excess holes
- P-N junctions form diodes

## Key Equations:

| Concept | Equation |
|---------|----------|
| Photon energy | E = hf |
| de Broglie | lambda = h/p |
| Mass-energy | E = mc^2 |
| Time dilation | t = gamma x t_0 |
| Half-life | N = N_0 x (1/2)^(t/t_1/2) |

## Impact on Technology:
- Electronics (semiconductors)
- Nuclear energy
- Medical imaging (PET, MRI)
- Lasers and LEDs
- GPS (relativistic corrections)

> **Congratulations!** You've completed Modern Physics. These revolutionary ideas form the foundation of 21st-century technology!
